positive.review: For the first three weeks I owned this game I put almost as many hours into it as I put into my actual paying job. With Museum, the Two Point franchise pivots from business sim to design sim and is all the stronger for it. Being able to create aesthetically pleasing things for the sake of aesthetic pleasure, and having the game reward this, means that I can continue to play each level long after achieving victory and still enjoy it. In Hospital and Campus, once you were making money hand over fist and had no more stars to get there was no real point in playing any longer, but by reducing the number of levels and allowing the player to really build up something that looks and feels amazing, play can go on indefinitely. Kudosh to Two Point Studios for their best franchise entry yet; now please let me choose what exhibits I'm recovering once I've Pristine-surveyed a point of interest, this (and a few more varied generic decorations) would make it much easier to customize museums exactly how I want.

NOTE: This is for version 7.0 Of the game

Hello friends,

Today I will be reviewing the game Two Point Museum. This game is part of the two point series which includes the two point hospital and two point campus. This is the third game made by two point studios.


Basically in this game, the player is a curator of a failing museum and must make it successful to make money. This is easier said than done, as the player must take expeditions to find new exhibits to place in the museum, then research information about exhibits to gain knowledge about them. Also, each exhibits can be upgraded, but it relies on the quality of the exhibit. Pristine exhibits allow you to upgrade three times, while lesser ones have only two or one upgrade slots. Not only can you have exhibits, but players can also put aquariums in their museums to feature fish, and with the newest upgrade, live animals. Although the newest dlc is currently not out yet, the developers provided a sample museum players can play on the map.

By having players develop the best museums, they can advance to other museums on the map and do the same thing. Each museum has it's own goals and trials, so players must learn to cope with new challenges. The hardest museums are the pop up ones, where players have a time limit to do something in them, such as having enough money from farming fish, or having enough buzz to get enough money.


PROS:

- A new game in the two point series featuring museum building.

- Players must make a museum successful.

- Sandbox mode and campaign mode.

- Many obstacles will stand in players ways, including criminals trying to steal museum exhibits.

- Cartoony graphics and silly exhibits. Many of the exhibits include silly things they are named or how they look. 

- New content will still be coming for the game, including new dlc's at this time.

- A seasonal map only open during seasonal events. Last one was for Halloween. Once you open them, you can keep items and decorations.

- Some of the maps are hard called pop up museums, and one museum called Pointy Mountain.



CONS:

- Some bugs with pathfinding in the museum maps. It causes people to get stuck, especially if you max out the size of the museum.

- Associated with the DLC Fantasy Finds, there is a bug when small races use watering fountains. The graphic makes them go into the water fountain.

- Some forum users also have reported several other bugs, but i have not run into these bugs personally.

- Some people are mad the pre order items and not enough floors are available to design their museums.



Do I recommend this game? Yes, although there are some bugs that need to be fixed, the game is quite fun if you like micro managing sims. This means players need to hire staff, build museum parts, watch out for criminals. The game can be that addictive "one more minute" kind of game if players are into this sim. Many of the games exhibits are also silly looking. This game does not take itself serious, but can be hard depending on the level of the players skills. So players who like micro managing things and building and even designing things may like this game.
The best title in the two point series so far. If you are a casual gamer, love tycoon games and fascinatied in decorating your dream museum, this is for you.
Amazing!!! I own all 3 two point games , Thumbs up for constant update & efforts but I have only one suggestion for the team. Add new game or start new game feature in story mode.

This game is so addictive. Takes the Theme Hospital formula and tweaks it just enough to be fresh and new without losing the core gameplay hook.
Lots of love went into making this.
Plus spooky museum ftw. Honestly, if it were only that I'd be here all day but there's more.

I love this game. I love the graphics the funny names, the tasks and the continued updates adding cool new things to do. This is my favourite 2 point game. Its the sort of game i keep coming back to over and over and there are new things to do each time

Really High Quality Experience!!! Over 100 hours of fun for me.

My first impression was that the variety & depth in game systems is much improved from Two Point Campus.
 
Each museum type has different exihibit mechanics, different balances of requirements for each world map, and unique quests for getting stars for each museum. 

The game juggles your attention, which keeps things engaging to me. Whenever one system lulls in the progression you can make on it, you can turn your attention to another game mechanic, while the others pick up. Hunting for actifacts, plot driven checklists to improve your museum rating and unlock content, the mastery of exhibit quality & knowledge, constantly expanding and decorating your museum, managing your staff and guests needs, preparing for future exhibitions, executing your ideas for interesting exhibit curations, improving the efficiency of the museum... wowie!

Both efficiency and aesthetics must be considered to make a popular (and crime free) museum, which I like. It's definitely on the easy side of a management simulation, but is juuuuuuuuust consiquential enough that it doesn't feel like a sandbox (a feeling I got with both Planet Zoo & Planet Coaster).

The attention to detail in the art direction is a big plus for me. I'm delighted and charmed by guests, exhibits, and the amazing audio from the DJs. The stylized Physical Based Rendering and lighting is so well done; it makes me just want to admire how beautiful everything looks. The Two Point world is so fun and goofy, and it is fantastically executed in this game!!!

I'm on a second run of the game now from the ground up, and I look forward to new DLCs, which have so far been very high quality too (Fantasy Finds) !

Two Point Museum shows that Mark Webley and Gary Carr still have the magic touch for turning everyday management into hours of fun. It’s an honest game that delivers heaps of content without slapping on a $100 price tag, and the studio keeps adding free updates instead of nickel‑and‑diming players.

Two Point Studios is proof that game development can be both fair and entertaining a model other companies should take notes from.

I've been playing for more than a hundred of hours and I've been loving every second of it. The graphism, the dialogues, the gameplay, the mechanics, everything is perfect. It gets challenging at the end of the story line when you're trying to get all the museum starts but that what makes it even better!

Even as an unabashed fan of all the Two Point Games, Two Point Museum is a delight. The exhibits are creative and fun, the interactive displays for kids are so cool, and the expeditions mechanic offers a rewarding challenge to strategize around. The best yet in a great series.

Having played both Hospital and Campus before, I was curious to see how Museum gameplay felt. Fell in love with the game and sank 50+ hours into it before I knew it. The dev team also communicates frequently on the dedicated Reddit sub to deal with issues  that are brought up. Defintely one of my favorite games this year.

Two point museum another great game.
More silly things, and tasks to do,
I prefer this one over the last two point 
I would recommend this game
10/10
Two Point Museum brings the wacky humour and unpredictability that early Sims games brought to the table, and I've missed that so much! My itch for an incredible game has been scratched :)

Great chill out game with surprisingly genuinely funny writing and delivery.  Normally the writing in comedy games is kind of forced and falls flat, but not here, including some really funny visual references to museum jokes like the Madgeburg Unicorn.

Pretty sure I’ve come down with a rather advanced case of “Broken Face” after discovering how many hours I’ve spent here.
The game’s absurd jokes absolutely destroyed me (in the most medically appropriate way) and the soundtrack politely kept me from realizing how deep into this obsession I’d fallen.
Truly, hats off to the developers for crafting a world so delightful that I apparently forgot to have a life outside of it.

P.S.: If I ever end up preserved in amber, please feel free to donate me to the museum. It seems only fair at this point.

Two Point Museum absolutely nailed it for me. If you’re into management sims that don’t take themselves too seriously, this one is ridiculously fun. It’s got that classic Two Point charm, goofy exhibits, bizarre guests, and all the little chaotic moments that keep you laughing while everything is slowly catching on fire behind the scenes (in the best way).

The gameplay loop is super satisfying: building out your museum, optimizing layouts, dealing with weird disasters, and trying to keep visitors happy while also making money. It’s easy to pick up but surprisingly deep once you start digging into it. And the humor? Peak Two Point. I caught myself grinning at random animations more times than I’d like to admit.

If you loved Two Point Hospital or Two Point Campus, this one is a no-brainer. It’s polished, hilarious, and insanely addictive. Highly recommend diving in, you’ll lose hours without even realizing it.

The Two-Point games kind of thrive on being able to build something that is both functional and aesthetic. A museum is a perfect platform for both, as aesthetics are the main point. But there is also efficiency to attain, which pleases the little optimization engineer inside me.

Plus, the expeditions are a perfect implementation of the experience of opening a loot box, without it actually being one. Well-designed game all around.

And quite funny too.

I just can't express how much I love this game. Two Point Studio's have this knack for making games that just scratch that management itch for me that most games haven't been able to do so. This game is a labor of love which is shown in every way.
amazing game, great follow on from the previous two point games and dev that support modding are always appreciated

I haven't put many hours in the game yet as I've been busy with my backlog of games but from what I played I loved it. It gives the same vibe as Zoo Tycoon with similar systems designed more for modern times. My only dislike is that you are sort of forced into playing on multiple museum types. Other than that I think the exhibit bonuses are done right with a grading system, the way you capture pieces of exhibits through expeditions is really addicting pushing you to try to complete a set. Overall a good solid game, I haven't personally experienced any bugs however I can't say for certain when it comes to NPCs and AI if there are no bugs there. It's worth it's asking price if you ask me.

The team really outdid themselves with this title- expeditions, quirky jokes and names signature to Two Point, the radio stations and art style, never fail to bring a smile to my face when chilling and winding down the day. 

Its refreshing to see the amount of love that goes into every detail. DLCs arent money grabbing. Exhibition variety is on point and don't we all love developers who listen to feedback? Its so nice to see how creative we can get with the props and items in game. Keep up the good work and here's to more future DLCs!
This is such a charming and relaxing game. Fantastic self care for a cozy winter afternoon.

Two Point Museum? Here are two points for ya, pal: 1. I like this a lot, 2. This game is really good. I have played some other Two Point games and enjoyed them but always bounced off for reasons that are hard to describe. Because of this I was skeptical of this game and hesitated to buy it despite the overwhelming praise it was getting. That lasted until a night of quiet contemplation and solo drinking in my office where I desperately needed a specific experience, a grounding experience that can only be achieved by a balanced, simple but deep management simulation. I added Two Points Museum to my cart and stumbled through the installation process. I instantly could tell that, while familiar, there was something different about this game compared to its predecessors. The systems made sense, the aesthetics and design, which admittedly are not my cup of tea, were cohesive and contributed to the atmosphere, the campaign had satisfying progression that was not just a glorified tutorial for sandbox mode. In short, if you are on the fence about this game, and you like management sims, go ahead and buy this playboy, you deserve it.

I love two point games, with each new release they are able to twist the gameplay and give a new experience to the player without changing the core of the game. Two point museum is clearly their best achievement so far and I can't wait to see what the next game will be.
Unironically one of my favorite management games i've ever played. enjoyable gameplay and atmosphere, easy to grasp mechanics, and funny moments all the time with absurd exhibits.
The best in the series, but I'd still like to see more depth in the economic management side of the game, it's just too easy to make loads of money.

Another solid game in the Two Point series. Not as fun or fleshed out as Hospital but still a great game. A bit more of a set it and go game, with less focus on customer satisfaction rates - the game instead focuses more on overall stats, but still really fun and engaging.

Definitely my favorite game of the Two Point series. The premise is fun as are the museum and exhibit themes.

TPM has the signature style of humor as the rest of the series. I find the increasing level of difficulty at each museum very well done - not too easy or too hard. At least with me and my play style I found the difficulty levels the best in this game out of the TP series.
The plot lines at each museum is another layer that makes game progression fun. The exhibits and exploration areas/worlds are also much more vast and expansive than I would have expected. Definitely not a game you’d get bored of quickly.

Hoping for more museums in the future as well as functional items. I find that with things like snack and drink machines, decor within rooms, and useable decor items like those in the staff room that’s there’s not a ton of variety so I’m always using the same items. More decor like that would be my biggest wish for future content.
Good game. Posting this 'review' for the meaningless Steam Awards participation badge.

I’ve only played about 12 hours of Two Point Museum, and this is my first time trying it, but it’s already got me hooked.

At the start, I was just placing a few displays and making a tiny gallery look presentable. Then more visitors showed up, weird problems started popping up, and suddenly I was stressing over a bathroom line that stretched halfway across the building while I was still obsessing over decorations. That pretty much captures the fun of it. You’re always trying to keep the museum running smoothly while also chasing profits.

Overall, if you enjoy management games with a playful tone, this one’s a good time. I’m still learning and my layout is a mess, but twelve hours disappeared before I even noticed. I’ll definitely be back trying to save my nearly bankrupt museum.
Easily my favorite of the Two Point games, they just keep getting better. Plays well with either mouse/keyboard or controller.

The Two Point series continues to be a lot of fun, and I am really enjoying the visuals and varied content for each museum. The ongoing updates and cross-game collaboration makes for fun "easter egg" experiences as well. This is a great game at full price, and an amazing value on sale.
I played Two Point Hospital and Two Point Campus and loved them so much - this one truly feels like it took the best of those two games.
Fun and silly game that's easy to relax whist playing. Don't take it too seriously and just enjoy making your dream museum of silliness.

Two Point Museum is everything I love about the Two Point games: goofy humour, smart management mechanics, and that “just one more tweak” addiction. Building exhibits is super fun, staff management feels smooth, and there’s always something ridiculous happening to keep you entertained.

Each level has its own vibe and challenges, and the game does a great job of letting you be creative without overwhelming you. 

If you enjoy management sims or just want a chill game that’ll steal your free time, Two Point Museum is absolutely worth it.
Probably my favourite of the TwoPoint series, it's a solid evolution on the management sim genre packed with easter eggs and humour

Wasn't quite sure what to make of how this game would work, but the innovative gameplay really distinguishes itself from Two Point's previous games to create a unique, charming appeal.

Game looks and feels good, has enough diversity of museums and missions to keep it entertaining, and plenty of regions to explore and unlock. Definitely has a way of sucking you in with a "One more expedition" feeling. I was surprised at how deeply engaged I got with the game, and with how quickly it sucked me in.

9.5 / 10 value. Quality gaming experience that definitely justifies to somewhat hefty price tag.

Highly recommend getting the base game on sale and bundled with some DLC, which are totally worth investing in to round out the experience and make all your musems feel unique.
Another great entry in the Two Point franchise.  Fun gameplay, quirky dialogue, and a great art style.  Really enjoying this title
Very enjoyable game! Lots of fun and I love the variations on the themes. Really well done and highly recommended!
Great twist on the series and a lot of fun to play. I hope they bring out some additional DLC for it!

I bought this game cause the missus said if I don't she'll leave me. 
I relucantantly played this. And Honestly (don't tell her this) I enjoyed it. 

It's quirky and funny. The soundtrack is great, the controls and progression is seamless. 
If you looking for a little game to sink a couple of 100 hrs into get it.

It's an amazing game.
Great to relax and unwind,∙very low stress
I can play this game like forever. If you into decorating and like management and little of british humor. This is it.
I think it's rather a simple concept, but done really overwhelmingly well. Good job. Get this game if you like progressive builders, with resources and economy. very good representation of the genre
Love the whole 2 Point series, but this one is my favorite.  Nice to just load the game and get lost for a few hours.  Recommend.
I've totally fallen in love with this game! I am a museum curator and it's 100% like this game lol
everything in this game feels so round and soft and eatable, oh yeah also good mechanics and stuff i guess
Fell in love with Theme Hospital as a kid and have loved the Two Point family of games. This one is the best one yet. LOVE IT! Relaxing, fun and goofy in the best way.
A game I actually might come back and play the dlc for
This is great game to play and relax after a long day away from the PC or the Console.  Can't really go wrong investing time building your museums.

I have been having a great time with this game. I love the ability to design and create my own museum. I like all the challenges you get to the complete. I really enjoy the variety of exhibits of all kinds that you can own. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys management games of any kind.

This game has gone from being the most difficult of the Two Point Franchise to get into to probably my favourite. 
Hospital will always have a place in my heart, as I was a massive fan of theme hospital. 
I'm coming up to 90 hours in Museum now, and haven't even touched the DLC other than a rudimentary look or gotten near to finishing - and one of the things I love about the game is you can make it as complex or simple as you want - and either just smash through the missions or take pride in your museum.  Definitely something for everyone.
Great management game. All the variety of museum themes and exhibits keep things fresh for a large amount of hours, all the while maintaining a steady trickle of new mechanics to unlock.
Builds on some of the gameplay in the other Two Point Games. Can be a little repetitive getting artefacts

Another cracking little game from TP studio!
Would love if the TP universe had more cross over between each game.
Great improvements over the last iterations of the Two Point -franchise. Expeditions are fun and the themes are great. Wonderful management sim.
Fantastic addition to the Two Point and park management game genre - expedition requirements are a great way to encourage return park visits
Just as much fun as Two Point Hospital and Two Point Campus.

Can be a little overwhelming with all the choices but once you get into a grove it's really fun. I love the different museum types, so much that I can't really say which I like the most, as they all have fun quirks to them

I'd recommend it. Silly ambiance, chill, casual. I finished the base game (5 stars on each of the 6 museum) in 49 hrs. So it joins the very limited set of games I finished. I'll look into the DLCs soon. Congrats Two Point Museum!

The idea is you're managing a Museum, send of your Indiana Jones to find dinosaur bones/rare fishes/spooky artefacts/sciency remnant/space magic/whatever. And when they come back, you can expose what they find in your museum. Then you must make it pretty by decorating, tend to the needs of your employees and visitors, and make a nice place.

They more or less avoided the topic of 19th-20th century british stealing all of the stuff of other countries. Oh well.

Great game,
Very fun game-play. Graphics, took me a bit to get used to but I now find them very fun and I love them, Always something to do. I easily sit their for hours, just one more thing then I'll leave it. Just one more. OK last one...
Love it! Quirky and deeply satisfying, perfect entry into the series.
When you open a Two Point game's lid you inevitably find a good management sim wrapped in humorous exterior. If you like the other Two Point games you will like this.
Fun relaxing game! Cute and always funny, never deceived by the Two Point games.

A very fun game, where you send groups to brave the wilds to bring back exhibits and place them and decorate around them for an aesthetic feeling or to fill the floor with as many exhibits as possible. Able to bring DLC exhibits into older maps which is a plus!

This game is so relaxing and fun. All the DLC and free content updates are amazing, and keep me coming back. I'm not usually one to complete every map, but the game makes it so fun and satisfying.  I think this is the best Two Point game yet!
This game is so fun I just love making my little cozy museum, how fun!
Silly and relaxing game which also scratches the collecting itch. Great puns as well

Great game for people like me, who love to hyperfocus away a few hours/days at a time micromanaging and fine tuning things. Cute graphics, funny puns throughout. Can be as complicated or as simple as you make it.

While there are times it gets boring and you feel timegated from more of the game, this game has been a great source of peace for me in a time most stressful. Also this game now has like twice the content from when I bought it so that was nice.

Like all Two Point games, Museum is incredibly addictive. Its really satisfying getting max-level exhibits, and arranging your museum to display it all. There is quite a broad range of exhibits and mechanics, too. You start out with fairly basic fossils, but later you unlock aquariums that you can decorate and populate with weird fish, scientific devices you can build and upgrade, and strange space anomalies that you have puzzle out to unlock their full potential. Every map comes with its own theme and set of mechanics, and once a map is unlocked you can mix and match exhibits in the same museum.

The music is catchy and never gets dull - though that might be helped by the radio-like interspersions from in-game DJs, which range from funny to hilarious. The general humour in the game is on-point (on-Two-Point, if you will, ohohoho). 

Rarely the museum decoration and customization options might not gel perfectly, but there is such a breadth of ways to design and decorate your museums that some small technical bugs cannot be avoided, and are usually fixed by just deleting something and replacing it.

My only real complaint about the gameplay is that there is no way to immediately repeat an expedition - each time you have to set up the expedition from scratch, meaning opening the map, choosing a location, choosing your staff from the staff list, choosing an item, etc. It would be nice if you could just click a button to "redo" the expedition with the same staff/loadout if you didn't quite get what you wanted the first time.

On the whole, the game is very good and highly addictive. And with the wealth of free updates and DLC the game has and is going to get, I can see me sinking many more hours into it.
Love the Two Poin series, it is a great spiritual successor to the Theme series, and Two Point Museum is the best yet!
This is the best title in the series so far. It's fun, quirky, and just challenging enough to be interesting. I love that they are continuing to update the game and offer DLC.
I love this franchise of games, from two point hospital, to campus and now museum... can't wait for the zooseum dlc!!
Super cozy, fun and addictive simulator with attention to detail and almost endless things to explore, all tied up in a intuitive UI. The humor is the cherry on top.

A great game to load up when you want to relax. Lots of fun with all the different themes that come with different challenges. 
The dry and sarcastic comments in the background to help you around the game add an extra touch that make you want to keep playing. 
Only a shame there is not a mode where all POI's are unlocked, so you can go full creative mode with the exact exhibits you want in your museum.

Good, wholesome fun. They've taken the ideas of Two Point Campus, improved in every area, then added some quality touches to the core game. It's a nice addition to the series, but Two Point Hospital remains the best of the three for me.
The best of the Two Point games so far! it's funny and charming and has so much content, amazing game!

Honestly, this is just better than Two Point Campus. I liked Campus, but Museum feels like it has way more content and actual stuff to do. Sending experts out to find artifacts is super fun and the decorating feels less restricted.

If you liked the other Two Point games, just get this one. It’s their best one yet.

I enjoy this game so much....actually more than university and hospital. I'm not the best at decorating but I keep trying. They kept what work across all their games and they listen to the community as well. I recommend this game.  As an avid D&D player, the fantasy dlc is my favorite and gives me a thrill every time I play it.
This game checks every box for my aching and constant anxiety

Two Point Museum is both a continuation of the wacky two point gaming we all know and love, plus a new spin on things, you send experts on expeditions to gather exhibits you can show off in your museums, bringing in profit and earning stars as you go. 

I think after the 2nd game, this seems to be a return to form. I have plenty of hours in the game and have enjoyed the new mechanics. The DLC and free updates are amazing and well worth getting at the reasonable prices. I particularly enjoy the digiverse additions as it opens it a lot of potential collaborations. 

I am very much looking forward to diving in to the zooseum expansion when that drops next week, the zooseum taster has been great and being able to try the DLC is a massivep plus in my eyes. I always come back to this great game!

Museums can be boring, or at least not as fun as schools or hospitals on paper, but Two Point Museum enhances the gameplay loop to make it enjoyable on every stage. Attention to detail, realistic animations and easily decorated places make this game even better.

Great game and easy to lose hours in. The different museum themes are a lot of fun and the mechanics behind each one is really engaging. Love the animation style and the tone and humour of the game too!

A fun management game. The exhibits and stuff around the museum has that charming Two Point feel, and offer a lot of variety. Building up your museum is fun and the progress in the game is nicely paced. The different locations offer unique challenges that spice up the maps.
Fun, but can get a little grindy, especially in campaign mode. Fun sense of humor and easy to get lost for hours playing.
The best game in the Two Point franchise. If you're looking to spend an evening playing a leisurely and funny game, Two Point Museum is a great choice.

welp.. I'm not ashamed to say it: I got addicted. UNFORTUNATELY, that lead to me being fired from my irl job because I kept staying up all night to play this game and had to call in too many times.. so I decided to become a real life two point museum curator! I hope these Kudosh are transferable to American dollars.. I wonder if there's a 401k? I wish the guests would stop motorboating the starfish fossil exhibit.. Anyway! Wish me luck!

Fun, but gets grindy

The latest entry in the Two Point series follows their now-familiar pattern of whimsical sim-style games. This time with museums.

And look, it is fun to play. If you’ve played other Two Point games, you’ll likely get exactly what you expect here. If you've played their previous games, you’ll almost certainly like this one… to a point (see below).

Seeing Stars…

Once you reach the 4–5 star levels, the game introduces unnecessary grind. Aside from placing exhibits and tweaking the museum layout to your liking, you’re mostly hit with 'meet these conditions and get a cookie' style tasks through expeditions. They start out ok and remain so for the most part, but eventually the conditions just become irritating rather than challenging. 'Hey, have a combined skill level of 30, otherwise the people you send will go missing!' (start again with a new staff member) Ha, take that player, how fun. No. not fun.

Why? Because the systems in place to get your staff to higher levels (and the time invested to do so), is in itself a bit grindy, or, clunky to achieve. It’s a weak part of the game. Want to level up a staff member? Ah-ha, make the player go to a ‘special’ expedition location, 15 times! They will love doing that for x30 staff members, what joy they will experience! No. No joy. 

From a gameplay perspective, the loop is 'trade time to get XP' but they’ve added unnecessary clicking and repetition. Let's make them click 20 times, per trip, to do it. I think functionally, you could of used the same trade, but instead had in museum items (in the staff room or training room), where staff could just sit and ‘learn’ (get xp), or remove a curses, etc, without the need to fluff about so much. Same result, less busywork. At this point the game started to overstay its welcome. Do I really want to sink another 10 hours just to finish the 5-star level, while playing at max speed, repeating the same loop to satisfy an irritating condition?

Nah. Not really.


On point (pun intended) with the expedition theme, they make you do the same thing again, but this time for exhibits, in the form of exhibit ‘quality’. This makes little sense. Again, why force the player to go do the same thing, but this time you got a slightly better version of the thing you already have! Yes, that was awesome! *blink*, *blink*. How about no, it’s not. Again, the mechanics are there, there is knowledge system, etc. Instead, I would have again preferred an ‘in museum’ system, where perhaps your experts could study the exhibits in order to unlock both knowledge, which in turn provided a higher tier of quality. The ‘go back again 20 times’ idea works when it’s a multi-part display that requires multiple pieces sure, but otherwise what am I supposed to be imagining here? The expert flys to a location where there is an endless supply of the same exhibit, and for some reason they are unable to identify what the good one looks like, unless they go back 25 times?


Look, I could go on,  but hopefully the point is clear.

The core gameplay and concept are absolutely there. The satire, the whimsical tone, the animations, the fake radio ads, all of it adds charm and character. But please: why do developers think grind mechanics  make a game better? This is a full release title. Give players a smooth, sensible gameplay flow all the way to the end.

Your model is clearly to release DLC with new museums and content, and that’s fine. If the base game is fun, people will happily buy more. Just because a movie could be five hours long doesn’t mean it should be. Sometimes the same story, or in this case, gameplay loop, can be just as impactful in one....

If you liked Two Point university you going to like this one too. To be honest its little simplified, but this way you can have more control over museum personnel, also devs put more and more themes, exhibits every few months for free so that is a win.
Now go check game for yourself and have fun!!!

just buy it, buy campus, and buy hospital get them all. well worth the money. these games make you laugh out loud. cutest animations. enjoy the upkeep and new gameplay added every time. honestly can not complain about any two point game i have played. very much enjoy every one.

This game is amazing! It is my favorite of their games and so engaging. I spend hours designing and redesigning my museum's. i love the stories and jokes. I love the different worlds and exhibits that it has. It is my comfort game after a hard day.
This is a great game. The gameplay is fun and humorous and there is loads of content. There are regular updates that bring fixes and new content. Highly recommend.

Fantastic game, great for casual play, very relaxing with lots to discover (and add to your museum!). If you didn't like the wave-format of TPH and TPC then fear not, because Museum opts more for a continuous sense of progression as you tweak and update and expand your museum. Instead of dozens of levels restricted to 3 tiers of goals, Museum gives you a handful of Museums, each with a specific theme in mind at the outset (though you can definitely grab Science and Necromancy exhibits for your Deep Sea museum!). You bounce between them as you gain stars, and each has a special mystery/reveal that you're trying to solve. It's a refreshing update to the classic format.

ALSO, the Developers are EXTREMELY active with this game. There are free timed seasonal events for time-limited rewards (they will return in the future for those with FOMO), free crossover digiverses with games like Dredge and Vampire Survivors, and even some free content updates that are not exclusive to DLC like previous Two Point games.

My only complaint is a relatively minor one, which is that the readily obvious humor of Hospital and Campus is much more subdued in Museum. Maybe it's because I'm used to it, but there's just less flavor text, fewer visual effects on many things (outside of certain sets of exhibits, I friggin' LOVE the Possessed Objects exhibits), and it feels a little more mature/serious despite how whacky things are. 

Definitely get this game if you enjoyed previous Two Point games or you want a relatively simple business management game with a ton to explore.

Another great sim that plays better and differently from Hospital and Campus.  The map system for getting new exhibits is the best addition, allowing you to get permanent improvements.  This makes it much easier to get more cash and easier starts in new areas which was a real problem in Hospital and Campus.  My only real issues are that some maps are oddly shaped making moving visitors through them kind of awkward, the other that some themes are much harder to get going than others.
Really fun, and relaxing by far my favorite Two Point game to date.
A wonderful, relaxing game, like all games in the Two Point series. Refreshing the formula with expeditions to collect artefacts for the museum works great. It keeps you hooked for hours.
I have spent many hours in Two Point County, this game is no different. The style of gameplay and the tone deliver what was promised way back in the Theme Hospital days.
I'm hooked, the game has everything I liked in Two Point Hospital, and many many new gameplay stuff I love. The anouncements are also a great fun highlight, perfectly voiced.
Considerably, one of the most fun games I've ever played and there's always something to do. Highly recommend.

negative.review: Don't feel any growth or development during the game. All he same mechanics and maps... Waste of time

[h2]Gacha/lootbox simulator[/h2]
It's repetitive from the very beginning. You don't manage much.
Back then i was glad to get Theme Hospital remake. And then studio made even cooler Two Point Campus. So the hype for Museum was real. I bought it and while you get used to mechanics you get that "novelty" sensation. But it got already stale after 2 hours.
Basically all grind consists of sending crew(s) on expedition(s), getting random thing, placing it. Repeat. And don't forget to throw bunch of decorations.

Hospital and Campus get repetitive too, but way later than Museum. In Museum there's not much of variety in gameplay. All strat is to send more expeditions. In Campus and Hospital player has some ways to experiment and explore and have fun while playing games. Museum is not fun. Maybe for kids it would be.

Support does not respond. I cannot sign on. Until they fix this issue and respond to new players I cannot recommend this game. I was signed in while playing Two Point Campus and it signed me out, I could never sign in to Two Point Museum. It claims it can't connect, I should check my internet connection. Blame the player, especially when this is an ongoing problem on your end, for YEARS.

Fix that.

The campaign makes the game. You can switch between the different museums so it always feels like there is so much to accomplish. Great game if I am being honest.  However, I play games for their sandbox experience. After 90 hours of grinding unlockables and enjoying the campaign, I wanted to make my ideal museum that would be a mega museum after learning all the expedition maps and overall design of exhibits. 

My negative review comes from the fact that the sandbox mode is not a true sandbox. First, there is no unlimited $$$ mode and the monthly grant doesn't seem to be working for me (could be a bug). Most importantly, after 90 hours of grind in the campaign, I just want everything to be unlocked in sandbox mode and I can pick and choose which expedition to do for specific exhibits I want for my mega museum. It feels like my campaign time had no value if I cannot have all expeditions at the very beginning of sandbox mode. 

As an example, at the start of sandbox mode, I wanted to make a large aquarium that just features coldwater exhibits. It would be a cool entrance to the museum and I mentally outlined the entire plot of what I want to build. But I can't get myself to play knowing that I need to unlock those coldwater expeditions again. I don't have the patience to temporarily place temperate fish in my museum just to unlock expedition maps to eventually unlock the coldwater expeditions. Its sandbox! I should be able to do whatever I want!

Purely from a personal enjoyment standpoint: I just can't get into it; I don't enjoy it, it isn't fun to me. I felt the same way about Two Point Campus, yet I really love Two Point HOSPITAL. There is something about the flow, the mechanics, the work-reward and humor that hooks me in Hospital that are missing in the other two.

I have no complaints about the design or execution of the game from a technical or graphical standpoint; I just could not get into it; after a brief time, I realized I was just going through the motions, and I wasn't enjoying it.

tldr: feels like the game's hiding important info from me for the luls, I'm over it

Somehow, my museum is unsustainable in the second map and I don't understand why. I check the graphs, check what visitors say and the satisfaction and there's just no explanation, apparently I sink most money into wages, but my staff are complaining that their wages are too small. Meanwhile, I've got like 80 people there at all times yet after raising ticket price I got 200$ more income, which makes no sense.

Also, someone gets possessed - which I only learn by seeing visitors run around of course - but I have no indication who it is, I can pause and check staff but even there it says nothing, then I can click on each staff member but then the window is so big it obscures the person it centers on, and their profile doesn't say they're possessed, so if I want to check, I have to close the window and zoom in so I can find the staff member amidst visitors... I'll just play a different game, thanks.

After 40 hours of playing the campaign I started sandbox mode. to my great disappointment the sandbox mode doesn't have everything unlocked, so they expect me to discover all the exhibits again, when I just want to relax and build my museum the way I want it. very disappointing.
Don't feel any growth or development during the game. All he same mechanics and maps... Waste of time

I love tycoon games like this so much. I really, really, really, really, dislike FOMO mechanics - cosmetics locked behind specific out-of-game interactions, like three now entirely unobtainable costumes, especially. 
I debated continuing playing for two weeks but knew deep down I wouldn't be able to stand the fact that I literally missed out on content because I didn't watch someone I didn't want to watch play the game.
